reviewerName: Aman Ashraff "'...life finds a way.' Ian Malcolm"
reviewText: Unlike other comedies I've had the pleasure to watch in my time, this has a very special place in my heart. And that's because of my father. An active politician in his own right, his life often mirrored the general lifestyle of the characters i.e. busy, on the move and hardly ever a private moment to himself. But on one particular weekend when he was at home, he walked into the living room and MY FELLOW AMERICANS was playing on the telly. I can still recall the laughter I heard that evening as I watched him enjoy the movie. And if someone like him found it 'laugh out loud funny',well then, 'NUFF SAID!
summary: "We hereby elect this one, A WINNER!"

reviewText: Well, we had Ronald Reagan as President, so why not (a) Jack Lemmon as Russell Kramer, a republican ex-president, (b) James Garner as Matt Douglas, a democratic ex-president, and (c) Dan Aykroyd as William Haney, the current republican president?Why not? Because you'll laugh so hard you'll get a stitch in your side, that's why!It seems there was a scandal brewing, and so President Haney's chief of staff and NSA chief Tanner (seriously psycho) cook up a scheme to pin the blame on President Kramer instead. But when the contractor at the center of the scandal is killed in the same car with President Douglas just seconds before President Kramer shows up, it is clear someone is trying to frame them for the murder.These guys are used to obeying the instructions of the Secret Service and other security types, so it takes them awhile to realize they are not being protected, they are being attacked. They escape from one attempt, only to run into one nasty mess after another.They are trying to get to Kramer's presidential library in Ohio, where he is confident that evidence of the truth is in the archives. They get unexpected help as well as unexpected dangers, though, and provide hundreds of laughs along the way. I won't spoil it for you, because the laughs will be bigger if you don't see them coming. And believe me, you won't see them coming. You will be at most one small step ahead of the ex-presidents as they attempt to do what they promised: to preserve, protect & defend the Constitution.They play out some party politics cliches, and reverse at least as many, and we can all have a good time with both. Five stars, one for each president, one for Tanner the psycho, and one for Dorothy. (You'll get it at the end.)
summary: Terrific Comedy by a Trio of Old Pros
Title: N/A

reviewText: The story covers several years and three presidencies. First Lemmon, then Garner and now Aykroid. Vice President Ted Matthews (John Heard) is a dunce. Turns out rumors of a scandal are surfacing and the now president is having thoughts of pining the scandal on Lemmon who was president at the time. Joe Hollis (Wilford Brimley) the head of the opposition party wants to pin it on the present administration. Col. Paul Tanner will protect the secret at any cost. There are many more players, too numerous to mention. Seems that someone has determined that Lemmon and Garner are best dispatched.Will this happen?Can they clear their names?And not just who is behind the plot, but what is the plot?Watch out for Blinky.This movie has a sound mystery base to get us through the twists and turns with lots of "who's behind it" moments. However the interaction between Garner and Lemmon is so much fun that sometimes we forget the plot.

reviewText: I found this to be a funny movie, and also very suspensful. It stars James Garner, and Jack Lemmon as 2 former presidents who are caught up in a fiasco that could wind up getting one of them into trouble, and the only way they can get to the truth is to work together, and get this: Lemmon's character is Republican, and Garner's is a Democrat. There's alot of bickering in this movie which just goes to show you what goes on in Washington, but they learn to work together, and eventually run for president together at the end of the movie. I guess this was a funny placebo to help with the indigestion that Washington is all about. I get rather tired of the partisan attitude that is politics as both sides work hard to show why they have all the answers. I just feel that it doesn't matter whether it's a republican, or a democrat just as long as the country runs smoothly. To be honest I would rather see more teamwork in Washington we vote these morons into office because we believe in what they promise, and then they just drop them when elected. I just get so fed up with Washington, and wish they'd all go away. Perhaps watching this movie will help Republicans and Democrats learn to work together.
summary: Now if only Washington can follow the advice from this movie

reviewText: Jack Lemmon and James Garner, as two aged ex-Presidents, romp through a workable script and funny gags, to provide an evenings entertainment. For those who were in their age cohort and saw them through long and successful careers, there was the added  pleasure of being reminded of just how good they were as actors as well as comedic actors (which is not the same as being comedians). The story line is just about adequate to hang the punch lines on, but that is almost irrelevant, the important thing being to enjoy the competitive thrust of the dialog. It's more than a little like a Hope-Crosby outing in a skit which has no other purpose than to give them a framework for put-downs. I should think the film would appeal to most people, although it lacks, for the most part, the saltier street language of more contemporary films.
summary: Two of the Best Romp Through a Middlin' Comedy

reviewText: Most modern movies that I can recall seem to be revolved around what is not real.  Stellar special effects and computer animation seem to riddle the plot of even the worst movies.  However, the decade old movie "My Fellow Americans" is a solid and refreshing comedy that defies this mold.The story line of the movie is rather plain.  Ex-President Kramer (Jack Lemmon) is being set up as the fall guy for a scandal committed during his presidency by his Vice-President (Dan Aykroyd), now current President.  Ex-President Douglas (James Garner) is President Kramer's nemesis and political rival.  President Douglas is trying to capitalize on the scandal in an attempt to possibly run for a second-term as President.  Through a twist of fate, the two Ex-Presidents suddenly find themselves having to work together to stay alive as the current administration is using the government intelligence agencies to track them down and kill them.  The result is a comedic road trip across the country in this unique game of cat and mouse.  Watching the Ex-Presidents interactions with the "common folks" is both comedic as well as heart-warming.In the hands of poor actors, this movie would have been terrible.  However, I feel Jack Lemmon and James Garner both gave a splendid performance and made this movie a great comedy.Due to the language, I would not call this a family comedy, but I would not hesitate to show to middle aged children.  If you are looking for a movie to kick back, relax, and have a few laughs, I would highly recommend this one.
summary: No Computer Animation or Special Effects, Just Great Acting

reviewerName: John S. Harris "The Voice of Reason"
reviewText: A friend made me watch this.  Now I owe her a favor.One of Lemmon's last films, MY FELLOW AMERICANS is an hysterical road trip movie, as two feuding and bickering ex-presidents try to figure out why they are targeted for assassination.  The cover-up goes ALMOST to the top.The dialogue is loaded with quick barbs and jabs, and the insults and the fur are flying!  Garner proved in "Support Your Local Sheriff" and its sequel that he is quite the comedic actor, and we already know about Lemmon's credentials.  Both are used in fine form here.  Even Lauren Bacall gets in on the act.This movie is yet another reason why we miss Jack Lemmon so.
summary: Great fun with Lemmon and Garner
Title: N/A

reviewText: "MY FELLOW Americans" is everything you could ever want in a  comedy. Sharp, caustic wits from Lemmon (as Russell Kramer) and Garner (as  Matt Douglas) combined with a downright hilarious plot makes this my #1  movie of 1996, my #24 of the 90's, and my #3 comedy of the 90's (behind #1  Bulworth and #2 Dogma). This would be an excellent one to go rent and  prepare for the election in November.The excellent comedic writing is  apparent ("There are only two watches like that in the world, Reagan  has one and now Shamu the Killer Hick has the other!"), and Heard's  underrated performance as Vice President Ted Matthews nearly steals the  show. (For those that have seen it, tell me his last line shouldn't be  ranked up there with other classic lines!) As usual, Lauren Bacall is  magnificent ("Don't say friggin', if you're going to use the F word go  for the gold"), and of course Jack Lemmon and James Garner turn in  great performances.The great cast, writing, and script idea all fold  together to make one of the best movies ever made.5/5.
summary: ONE OF THE BEST COMEDIES EVER MADE...INTELLIGENT AND SHARP

reviewText: I wanted to see this movie originally for Dan Ackroyd.  I'm a fan of Dan's, and try to see everything he's in.  That was my original reason for seeing this.However, the Lemmon/Garner pairing was great!  Once I realized that Ackroyd's chracter isn't a major player in the movie, and it really was a buddy movie between Lemmon & Garner, it took on a whole new tone.Not to mention the fact that these actors were brilliant.  They're from a generation of actors that just ooze professionalism.  Most of today's actors haven't been around long enough to get that, but these guys were rock solid.  Loved it!  Funny movie, you can't go wrong here.Lemmon died the day I wrote this - we'll miss him, he was a great actor!
summary: A great funny movie - a surprise, too!

reviewText: This is a rapturous comedy of two ex-presidents who have spent their political careers as arch-enemies. When a psycho named Tanner teams up with the powers that be to frame them both for a cover-up, the two foes must forge a fellowship to prove their innocence before their luck runs out.As the former Presidents Kramer (Lemon) and Russell (Garner) trail the American roads trying to escape their foes  ... they meet a homeless couple living in their trailer, march in a Gay Pride parade, ride in the back of a motorcycle with Lesbians, hijack a college train bound for Cleveland, and run into illegal Mexicans hiding from Immigration. Both see the daily impact of their policies and solve the crime behind their being framed. Probably the most hilarious scene is when the two men are riding stolen police horses to the south lawn to interrupt the speech of the current President to prove they are still alive. They are almost done in by Tanner until a Gay Pride Lieutenant pal re-directs his fire to save them, all believing that President Kramer is in the closet because he is wearing a Gay Pride bracelet.This is one political joke after the other and very telling even a decade after it was produced. One of the kinds of films you can watch over and over again.
summary: Hail and Holler and Laughter to the Chief

reviewText: According to the IMDB, Walter Matthau was originally paired with old sidekick Jack Lemmon in this spoof.  While Matthau and Lemmon were a great team, James Garner stepped in and made a fine match with Lemmon.  The joy in this movie is watching pros like Lemmon and Garner make the most of their dialogue and comic situations.  They both toss off some great one-liners, and make MY FELLOW AMERICANS a thoroughly engaging comedy.  John Heard as a Dan Quayle copy is effective and Dan Aykroyd wisely underplays his role as the current president.  Nice supporting bits, too, from Lauren Bacall, Bradley Whitford, Everett McGill and Esther Rolle, too.  While not a major hit, this movie is still fun to watch especially for Lemmon and Garner.

reviewText: This was one of the funniest movies ever. Lots of laughs! Jack Lemmon and James Garner were terrific playing ex-presidents who once let the nation and have become "civilians." One is a womanizer (hmmmm who does this remind you of????), and the other, a known cheapskate where his one line is," Dreams are like children, they need to be nutured and be allowed to grow."The ex-presidents are (first Lemmons character and then Garner who is guilty bu association by the NSA) framed in a scandal that was actually commited by the president who is in office, President Kramer (Dan Aykroyd). What you notice most of all is President Kramer's vice president played by John Heard. You can pretty much sense his worth when President Kramer says," lets hope Vice President Mathews knows it's the Netherlands, not the nether-region." Everett McGill (who starred in The People Under the Stairs and Under Siege 2) who excells as a bad guy, plays NSA agent Tanner who will stop at nothing to silence Presidents Kramer (Lemmon) and Douglas (Garner). After an unsuccessful attempt to silence them permanently, he stops at nothing to get it done. In the meantime, the ex-presidents go on a madcap adventure to clear their names. Whether they hitch a ride with illegals or coming out of the closet with Dorothy. All this leads up to is a hillarious comedy starring 2 legends along with a teriffic supporting cast.The DVD is a basic edition with no extras. If you love comedies you will laugh hysterically. In your DVD library it will make your other DVD's laugh nonstop. April Fools!!!!! But it is funny and a great addition to your collection.
summary: "Russell, when you dance with a panda, who leads?"

reviewText: Republican Russell Kramer (Jack Lemmon) beat Democrat Matt Douglas (James Garner) for President in a very tight race.  Four years later Douglas beats Kramer.  Four years later Kraemer Vice President William Haney (Dan Aykroyd) defeats Douglas.Three more years have passed. Kraemer is now making paid public appearances and writing books on any subject.  Douglas has more noble goals, nailing every babe he can.  Then a scandal is about to break out and Douglas and Kramer find out.  Since he can no longer shift blame to Kramer, Haney decides to kill the former Presidents.The plot fails but leaves the Presidents stranded.  They must find the proof that Haney is guilty and get back to DC alive.  This starts a cross country chase that is constantly funny including the Presidents becoming involved in a gay pride parade - that saves their life!I have to guess that this was originally conceived as a Lemmon Matthau film but was too physical for the declining Matthau.  It actually works better with Garner as he is more believable as the Clintonesque womanizer.Lauren Bacall is great as Mrs. Kramer but only has a couple of scenes.  Marg Helgenberger (pre CSI) makes an appearance as Douglas' book editor.  And Bradley Whitford makes a White House appearance two years before he took up residence with the Bartlett administration in The West Wing.It's too bad that Lemmon died before he could reteam with Garner.  They made a great pairing.DVD EXTAS: Blooper Reel.
summary: Lemmon Less Matthau Plus Garner - and Bacall

reviewText: Though a moderate success when first released, "My Fellow Americans" (1996) has more resonance now that the Bush Administration is drawing to a close. In their only film together, Jack Lemmon and James Garner prove an inspired match with this entertaining political farce. It's pure pleasure watching these old pros work and their razor-sharp chemistry transforms a less-than-brilliant script into comic gold. Far superior to the Lemmon-Matthau "Grumpy Old Men" movies.
summary: Lemmon and Garner Make a Classic Team

reviewText: I am not a lover of dumb comedy. I don't like crude or rude and physical comedy, in general, is just not my bag. In fact, you couldn't pay me to watch ANY of the movies listed in the "frequently bought together" category by Amazon for this film. I have even been accused of being a movie snob. And yet, I truly love "My Fellow Americans," and laugh each and every time I see it, something that's pretty rare.Maybe it's the genius combination of Garner and Lemmon, two icons of the industry (not to mention the fabulous Lauren Bacall), or maybe it's the actually quite sharp commentary on our political system, or the simply laugh-out-loud comedic timing of the two leads. "My Fellow Americans" is a buddy comedy that has far more in common with "Midnight Run," or a political satire in the spirit of "Dave," than the dreck Lemmon did with Walter Matthau.To me, this is an undiscovered gem, with plenty of classic lines my husband and I can quote back and forth to each other that make us giggle (Bacall has most of them, e.g. "Don't say friggin'. If you're gonna' use the f-word, go for the gold.") and a good heart.On a personal note, my now husband and I actually saw this originally, one New Year's Eve when we were newly dating. We had planned to see "Titanic" but it was so long it would have kept us in the theater past midnight. Ever since, it's become one of our sentimental favorites and we watch it every couple years and always laugh. (And, FYI, though we did, like every other person on the planet, eventually see "Titanic," and thought it was fine, I've never watched it again ... Or had any desire to.) And, at the risk of TMI, we actually took this DVD to the hospital with us when we had our son. So, yes, this movie is so cute and light-hearted I actually laughed while in labor ... And if that's not a poster-worthy blurb, I don't know what is.
summary: Classic Buddy Comedy; An Under-Rated Gem

reviewText: Jack Lemmon and James Garner play a couple of squabbling ex-presidents.They find out what it is like to be a working class person in the wakeof there policies. Along with getting framed for someones elses bad deeds,  to prove there innocence. Dan Aykroyd plays the President,so with allthe laughs there is still a good whos done it movie.Check this one outbecause you would beleave who did it!

reviewText: 4and1/2 Stars.  I first saw this delightful movie near the end; and, was intrigued enough to getit.  Loved it.  I then showed it to my Yellow Dawg Dem Parents.  They loved it and have seen ittogether twice.  Garner did a nice job as a Clintonesque Dem Prez; but, Lemmon just can't geta handle on what even a Rockefeller Republican is like; but, I really loved the kibbitzing betweenGarner and Lemmon and one ups-manships.I'm going to see it again with my Mother next month.  I don't remember this at the movies!Luv most Jim Garner movies!

reviewText: At first glance, this looks one of Hollywood's freakier genetic experiments: implanting the genes of a political thriller into a road-trip comedy. The surpise is that the offspring is not just viable, but a good healthy comedy. It surely helps to have two fathers like James Garner and Jack Lemmon bringing it to life.They play the roles of two ex-presidents, living out their retirements in their respective ways: grubbing every dollar to be had on the lecture circuit (Lemmon), or grabbing every babe to be had (Garner). Dan Aykroyd, improbably cast as the current president, detects a scandal brewing and tries to nail it to the previous administration. Garner and Lemmon, one-time political opponents, are thrown together and the chase begins.The comedy comes largely from the series of cheap shots and snide recollections the two hurl at each other. The feel-good part comes from their bonding over shared experiences as past presidents, under the pressure of pursuit. The political thriller builds as the hired guns keep trying to assassinate the ex-pres, and to bury the scandal with him. As long as you're not looking for any great subtlety, it works.It's a bit goofy, but it's a good, safe comedy with just enough plot twists to keep it from becoming completely predictable. It couldn't have worked without Garner and Lemmon in the lead roles, though - their experience in such roles is what made the movie work.//wiredweird
